question: Does this paper involve the theory "A Model of Personal Informatics"?
extracted_search_list: Does this paper involve the theory "A Model of Personal Informatics"?
searched_docs:
Model of Personal Informatics Systems. Proc CHI, 557–
566. 56.Li, I., Dey, A.K., & Forlizzi, J.
(2012). Personal informatics in practice. Proc CHI Ext. Abst., 2799-2802.

As  mentioned  above,  the  Personal  Informatics
model  described  reflection as “looking at lists  of  collected
personal  information  or  exploring  or  interacting  with
information  visualizations,”  [55:562].
Personal informatics in the wild. Proc CHI Ext. Abst., 3179-3182.

Interestingly,  although  reflection  plays  a  prominent  role  in
personal informatics and related work, the final stage of Li
et  al.’s  [55]  model,  and  the  goal  of  much  similar  work,  is
action.

72.Pirzadeh, A., He, L., and Stolterman, E. (2013). Personal
informatics and reflection: a critical examination of the 
nature of reflection.

While  this  rhetorical  positioning  comes  across  clearly  in
personal informatics, many papers in our review that were
not identified by the authors under that umbrella still cited
similar  motivations.

Int. J. Hum.-Comput. Stud., 
67(4), 394-410. 62.Malacria, S., Scarr, J., Cockburn, A., Gutwin, C., and 
Grossman, T. (2013).
ubicomp technologies. Proc UbiComp, 405-414. 57.Li, I., Forlizzi, J., and Dey, A.K.

(2008). Push-me, pull-me: 
describing and designing technologies for varying 
degrees of reflection and invention.

Their line of reasoning suggests that showing users
data  about  themselves  will  lead  them  to do  something,
presumably  something  different  from  and  better  than  what
they  are  already  doing.

(2011). Understanding 

my data, myself: supporting self-reflection with 

New York: Perseus Group.

For  example, Mathur  and  Karahalios
describe  a  visualization  system  based  on  bookmarks  in  a
web  browser  wherein  “the  user  is  able  to  notice  things
about  oneself  that  he  or  she  did  not  notice  before”
[65:4657].

(2010). Know thyself: 
monitoring and reflecting on facets of one's life.

This  definition
carries  an  implicit  assumption  that  by  providing  access  to
data  that  has  been  “prepared,  combined,  and  transformed”
[55:561] for the purpose of reflection, reflection will occur.

Indeed,  the  idea  of  inciting  behavioral
change occurred implicitly in much of the papers reviewed
here.

(2010). A Stage-Based 

71.Norman, D. A. (1993). Things That Make Us Smart.
Proc DIS, 145-154. 54.Leong, T. W., & Brynskov, M. (2009).

The Constitution of Reflection
Many  of  the  papers  in  this  review  described  interventions
designed  to  support  or  encourage  reflection  in  some  way.

However,  these  papers  also  varied  in  the  degree  of
prescribing  exactly  of  what  that  behavioral  change  should
consist, raising comparisons with persuasion.

Skillometers: reflective widgets 
that motivate and help users to improve performance. Proc UIST, 321-330.
Proc IDC, 129-132. 55.Li, I., Dey, A.K., & Forlizzi, J.

Desiring to be in touch in a changing communications 
landscape.

Proc 
CHI Ext. Abst., 4489-4492. 58.Li, I., Froehlich, J., Larsen, J.E., Grevet, C., and 

Ramirez, E. (2013).
60.Lindley, S.E., Harper, R., and Sellen, A. (2009).

CO2nfession: 
Engaging with values through urban conversations. Proc OZCHI (pp.

(2000). Two-dimensional spatial positioning as a 
means for reflection in design.

However, the lack of definition or deeper engagement with
the  concept  of  reflection  poses  challenges  for  design.

representations of moving bodies for interactive, 
motion-sensing spaces.
